revision.text:
'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]], see [[seismology]]
It is published in his book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals ISBN 0963601288
{{msg:stub}}
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]], see [[seismology]]
It is published in his book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals ISBN 0963601288
{{geol-stub}} [[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]], see [[seismology]]
The underlying principles are discussed in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0963601288
{{geol-stub}} [[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and the location of underground mineralized structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The underlying principles are discussed in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0963601288
See also [[seismology]].
{{geol-stub}} [[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The underlying principles are discussed in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0963601288
See also [[seismology]].
{{geol-stub}} [[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The underlying principles are discussed in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0963601288
==See also==
* [[seismology]]
{{geol-stub}} [[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected. Kyle is cool

revision.text:
'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The underlying principles are discussed in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0963601288
==See also==
* [[seismology]]
{{geol-stub}} [[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

'''Telegeodynamics''' is a mechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The underlying principles are discussed in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8
==See also==
* [[seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

revision.comment: Added sentence including the word "isochronous" and modified citation
revision.text:
'''Telegeodynamics''' is an electromechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous]], that is to say, frequency stable, alternating electric current used with both wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus.
The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the Lucas Method of Prospecting by Detonations of Explosive Compounds and of The Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations Theoretically Considered" available in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8
==See also==
* [[seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]
{{geol-stub}}

'''Telegeodynamics''' is an electromechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous]], that is to say, frequency stable, alternating electric current used with both wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus.
The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the Lucas Method of Prospecting by Detonations of Explosive Compounds and of The Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations Theoretically Considered" available in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8
==See also==
* [[Seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]
{{geol-stub}}

'''Telegeodynamics''' is an electromechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]]. He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected. [Telegeodynamics was later robotics]
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous]], that is to say, frequency stable, alternating electric current used with both wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus.
The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the Lucas Method of Prospecting by Detonations of Explosive Compounds and of The Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations Theoretically Considered" available in the book, Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals, Leland Anderson and Gary Peterson, editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8
==See also==
* [[Seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]
{{geol-stub}}

'''Telegeodynamics''' is an electromechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]].<ref>Telegeodynamics was later incorporated into his concepts of robotics</ref>
==Description== He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous frequency|isochronous]] (that is to say, [[frequency stable]]), [[alternating current|alternating electric current]] used with both [[transciever|wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus]]. In [[dynamical system |dynamical system theory]] an [[oscillator]] is called ''isochronous'' if the frequency is independent of its amplitude. A [[electromechanical]] device which runs at the same rate regardless of changes in its [[prime mover|drive force]], so it keeps correct [[frequency]] ([[hertz|hz]].
==References== Citations {{reflist|1}} Notes * The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the [[Lucas Method]] of [[Prospecting]] by [[Detonation]]s of [[Explosive Compound]]s and of The Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations Theoretically Considered]]" (ed., available in the book, ''Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals'', [[Leland Anderson]] and [[Gary Peterson]], editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8
==See also==
* [[Seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]
{{geol-stub}}

'''Telegeodynamics''' is an electromechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]].<ref>Telegeodynamics was later incorporated into his concepts of robotics</ref>
==Description== He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial acoustic impulses may also be detected.
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous frequency|isochronous]] (that is to say, [[frequency stable]]), [[alternating current|alternating electric current]] used with both [[transceiver|wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus]]. In [[dynamical system |dynamical system theory]] an [[oscillator]] is called ''isochronous'' if the frequency is independent of its amplitude. A [[electromechanical]] device which runs at the same rate regardless of changes in its [[prime mover|drive force]], so it keeps correct [[frequency]] ([[hertz|hz]].
==References== Citations {{reflist|1}} Notes * The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the [[Lucas Method]] of [[Prospecting]] by [[Detonation]]s of [[Explosive Compound]]s and of The Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations Theoretically Considered]]" (ed., available in the book, ''Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals'', [[Leland Anderson]] and [[Gary Peterson]], editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8
==See also==
* [[Seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]

'''Telegeodynamics''' is an electromechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]].<ref>Telegeodynamics was later incorporated into his concepts of robotics</ref>
==Description== He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial [[Electrotelluric|electrotelluric]] impulses may also be detected.
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous frequency|isochronous]] (that is to say, [[frequency stable]]), [[alternating current|alternating electric current]] used with both [[transceiver|wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus]]. In [[dynamical system |dynamical system theory]] an [[oscillator]] is called ''isochronous'' if the frequency is independent of its amplitude. A [[electromechanical]] device which runs at the same rate regardless of changes in its [[prime mover|drive force]], so it keeps correct [[frequency]] ([[hertz|hz]]).
==References== Citations {{reflist|1}} Notes * The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the [[Lucas Method]] of [[Prospecting]] by [[Detonation]]s of [[Explosive Compound]]s and of The [[Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations]] Theoretically Considered" (ed., available in the book, ''Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals'', [[Leland Anderson]] and [[Gary Peterson]], editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8

In [[dynamical system |dynamical system theory]] an [[oscillator]] is called ''isochronous'' if the frequency is independent of its amplitude. A [[electromechanical]] device which runs at the same rate regardless of changes in its [[prime mover|drive force]], so it keeps correct [[frequency]] ([[hertz|hz]]).
==References== Citations {{reflist|1}} Futher reading * The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the [[Lucas Method of Prospecting by Detonation]]s of [[Explosive Compound]]s and of The [[Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations]] Theoretically Considered" (ed., available in the book, ''Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals'', [[Leland Anderson]] and [[Gary Peterson]], editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8 * Journal Il Nuovo Cimento C, ''On a new general theory of earthquakes''. Italian Physical Society, ISSN 1124-1896. Issue Volume 11, Number 2 / March, 1988 DOI 10.1007/BF02561733 Pages 209-217 SpringerLink Date Thursday, February 08, 2007
==See also==
* [[Seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]
{{geol-stub}}

'''Telegeodynamics''' is an electromechanical earth-resonance concept for underground seismic exploration proposed by [[Nikola Tesla]].<ref>Telegeodynamics was later incorporated into his concepts of [[robotics]]</ref>
==Description== He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial [[Electrotelluric|electrotelluric]] impulses may also be detected.
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous frequency|isochronous]] (that is to say, [[frequency stable]]), [[alternating current|alternating electric current]] used with both [[transceiver|wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus]]. In [[dynamical system |dynamical system theory]] an [[oscillator]] is called ''isochronous'' if the frequency is independent of its amplitude. A [[electromechanical]] device which runs at the same rate regardless of changes in its [[prime mover|drive force]], so it keeps correct [[frequency]] ([[hertz|hz]]).
==References== Citations {{reflist|1}} Futher reading * The underlying principles are discussed in Tesla's paper, "Relative Merits of the [[Lucas Method of Prospecting by Detonations of Explosive Compounds]] and of The [[Tesla Method of Prospecting by Isochronous Oscillations]] Theoretically Considered" (ed., available in the book, ''Nikola Tesla's Teleforce & Telegeodynamics Proposals'', [[Leland Anderson]] and [[Gary Peterson]], editors, Twenty First Century Books, 1998, ISBN 0-9636012-8-8 * Journal Il Nuovo Cimento C, ''On a new general theory of earthquakes''. Italian Physical Society, ISSN 1124-1896. Issue Volume 11, Number 2 / March, 1988 DOI 10.1007/BF02561733 Pages 209-217 SpringerLink Date Thursday, February 08, 2007
==See also==
* [[Seismology]]
[[Category:Nikola Tesla]]
{{geol-stub}}

==Description== He designed this system for use in prospecting and discerning the location of underground mineral structures through the transmission of mechanical energy through the subsurface. Data from reflected and refracted signals can be analyzed to deduce the location and characteristics of underground formations. Additional non-mechanical responses to the initial [[Electrotelluric|electrotelluric]] impulses may also be detected.
The electromechanical oscillator was originally designed as a source of [[isochronous frequency|isochronous]] (that is to say, [[frequency stable]]), [[alternating current|alternating electric current]] used with both [[transceiver|wireless transmitting and receiving apparatus]]. In [[dynamical system |dynamical system theory]] an [[oscillator]] is called ''isochronous'' if the frequency is independent of its amplitude. A [[electromechanical]] device which runs at the same rate regardless of changes in its [[prime mover|drive force]], so it keeps correct [[frequency]] ([[hertz|hz]]).
